. - I wish to pay a tribute to the department in connexion with the manner in which war graves are being maintained. It was my privilege to go to Papua and New Guinea for the Anzac Day celebrations this year. A delegation consisting of three members from the Government side and three members of the Opposition went there from this Parliament. I was particularly impressed by the work that had been done in the war cemetery at Lae, in New Guinea. I believe that a very small staff, consisting of one European and seven native people, is responsible. It was a truly remarkable sight to see the perfect manner in which the graves were tended.

speech.para: I wish this evening to refer to the responsibilities of the department for war graves overseas. I have in my hand the annual report of the Commonwealth War Graves Commission, which was formerly the Empire War Graves Commission. The responsibility of the commission is worldwide and covers cemeteries wherever Empire soldiers who served in the First World War and Commonwealth soldiers who served in the Second World War are buried. I refer particularly to page 80 of the report, where reference is made to the graves in the United Arab Republic. It should be remembered that those who fell at El Alamein are buried in that area, about 60 or 70 miles from Cairo. I was struck by the fact that no mention is made in the report of the Australian Government having played a part in the annual service of remembrance at the El Alamein war cemetery. The service was held in 1960 on 23rd October. On 30th October, Italian diplomatic and service representatives in Egypt laid wreaths at the El Alamein war cemetery, and even a member of the German community laid a wreath on 8th November.

I am pleased to learn from the Minister for External Affairs (Sir Garfield Barwick) that this year, the twentieth anniversary of the Battle of El Alamein, Mr. Stuart, the Australian Ambassador to the United Arab Republic, will be at the commemoration ceremony and will lay a wreath on behalf of the Australian Government. He will be accompanied by officers of the Embassy. I direct attention to this matter because I think that our Department of External Affairs should see to it that these war graves all over the world, where Australian dead are buried, should not be accounted for merely by a budget entry showing that we are providing £301,300 for the maintenance of the graves. We have Australian representatives throughout the world and they should be encouraged, and directed, if necessary, to attend ceremonies which are held on the focal day of the year associated with the cemeteries in their areas. 1 commend the Government for complying with the wish of some of us that His Excellency the Ambassador, the most senior representative of Australia in the area, will be present at the ceremony to mark the twentieth anniversary of the Battle of El Alamein.

I also wish to commend the Commonwealth War Graves Commission for the magnificent work it is doing throughout the world - in England, in France, in Egypt, in the United Arab Republic, in the Eastern areas and also in the Pacific areas. The commission is doing work of an abiding nature. I ask that in future personnel from Australian legations, trade missions and trade posts should, whenever possible, show the interest of the Australian people by being present at ceremonies at war cemeteries.

talk.start.para: . - Can the Minister inform me when the Anzac Memorial at Port Said, which is being reconstructed and re-erected in Western Australia, will be completed? Will notice be given to the Senate of the official unveiling ceremony at Albany? I also wish to refer to the subject of war graves. I was privileged to see some of the war cemeteries in Europe, but at the moment I propose to refer to the war cemeteries in Australia, particularly those in which soldiers who died since the war have been buried. I commend the Commonwealth War Graves Commission for the care which it takes over those graves. Unfortunately, I have relatives who are buried in such cemeteries, including two brothers-in-law.

speech.para: I ask the Minister to consider the case of ex-servicemen of World War I. who suffered war injuries and were in receipt of a pension for those injuries at the time of their death but whose death was not directly attributable, according to the department, to their war injuries. Therefore, their relatives are not permitted to have the insignia of the rising sun, and so on, placed

Estimates Papers1962-63. [1 7 October, 1 962.] Estimates Papers 1962-63. 925 on their graves. 1 refer particularly to a case which was brought to my notice some little time ago. It concerned a man who had won the Military Medal and been mentioned in despatches. He had enlisted in World War 1., was severely wounded on three occasions, and later enlisted in World War II. He was in receipt of a quite substantial pension for his war disabilities. He died in a military hospital, but his death was not attributable to the injuries he had received. The decision was that it was due to the effluxion of time. 1 am inclined to disagree with that decision. His widow approached me to see whether a headstone could be erected over his grave, even if it were necessary to have it erected at her own expense. This may be only an isolated instance, but I think that quite a number of our World War I. and World War II. veterans are now approaching the time of life when their death could be hastened by their wartime experiences and the injuries they suffered.

It would be a worthwhile gesture to extend the service which is given by the Commonwealth War Graves Commission in this regard. To do so would not involve the expenditure of a great deal of money, but it would mean much to the relatives of men who offered their lives in war service. Some of them were wounded during the war, and some died in necessitous circumstances, or as pensioners. That would not only be a very humane action, but it would also give some comfort to the bereaved relatives.

talk.start.para: - That would mean that every ex-serviceman who died would be entitled to a war grave.

- Not necessarily. I am asking only that those who have been in receipt of a pension for war injuries be given a war grave. I do not think that this would involve a great deal of expense. In any event, even if the principle were extended to the extent envisaged by Senator Kendall, it would not be a very big price to pay for the sacrifices which these people were prepared to make at the time when their country needed them most.
. - 1 refer to Division No. 687, which relates to war graves overseas. Last year,

speech.para: I had the opportunity to visit the war cemetery at a place called Kanchanaburi in Thailand, and I should like to place on record the fact that I found that cemetery to be wonderfully well cared for. It was beautifully kept, and was a most fitting memorial to those who died there. It might be of interest to the Senate to know that the Kanchanaburi cemetery is situated on the site of what was a big temporary asylum to which prisoners of war were brought prior to be taken back to Singapore after working on the railway. Our medical officers did a magnificent job in trying to cure or save the very many thousands of sick men who were brought to them. Many men died there. The Kanchanaburi cemetery is quite close to the River Kwai, which attracted a great deal of interest in recent times because of the fact that a movie depicting the story of the building of a railway there by prisoners of war was exhibited.

My visit to this cemetery was an emotional occasion because I was returning to the place at which I was very sick myself, and at which I was treated by some of our medical men who did a magnificent job. Many acts of great courage and devotion were seen there.

Kanchanaburi is a fairly inaccessible place. To get there one must drive about 80 miles from Bangkok and, much as many parents and loved ones of the deceased soldiers would like to go there, they would have great difficulty in getting to the cemetery. To those who do make the journey, it is a very exhausting pilgrimage, and I feel that there ought to be some sort of resting hut nearby to which the people who visit the cemetery can have access. The cemetery is on holy, dedicated land, and one does not want to stay there and relax. When one visits a cemetery one wants to be able to think of the past, and of the men who died there, and it would be a very fine gesture if a rest hut could be erected, perhaps 100 yards away or somewhere across the road from the cemetery.

My sole purpose in rising was to place on record the appreciation of a humble soldier of that period of the fact that the War Graves Commission is doing a magnificent job, and the loved ones of the soldiers at rest there can take comfort in the thought that the cemetery is so very well cared for.

talk.start.para: . - I pay tribute to Senator Laught and Senator Anderson for their appreciation of what the War Graves Commission is doing to maintain in such wonderful order the last resting places of so many of our gallant young men. The least I can do is to say that I shall suggest to my colleague that he convey to the people responsible for rendering this splendid service the contributions made by both Senator Anderson and Senator Laught to this debate. These people are far from us, and we are inclined to take for granted what they do. But we all concede that to walk into some of the cemeteries is a most sobering and wonderful experience.

Senator Sir WALTERCOOPER (Queensland) [9.48]. - I refer to item 08 of sub-division 2, of Division No. 688, which relates to the printing of volumes of the "Official War History". The amount to be appropriated this year is £10,000. Last year, the appropriation was £52,000, of which £43,010 was expended. I should like to know the stage which the printing of this official war history now has reached. Will the £10,000 cover the work necessary to complete it?
I should like to know also what is covered by the provision of £13,100 for library, cinema and photographs. Is that money to be expended on the museum, or is it to be used for some other purpose?

talk.start.para: . - Senator Sir Walter Cooper is correct in assuming that the printing of the official war history is tapering off. An amount of £10,000 is to be appropriated this year, to provide for the completion of the printing of one volume and for work in progress in connexion with two others. Printing of new volumes will be much less in 1962-63 than in 1961-62, and £10,000 is adequate to meet requirements.

speech.para: The honorable senator asked also about the provision of £13,100 for library, cinema and photographs. Provision has been made for normal photographic requirements, classifying, cataloguing, &c, and for making photographic prints of official photographs of which negatives only are available. Provision is also made for materials for the mounting of record photographs, and continuation of recopying of selected cinefilms of both world wars which have deteriorated and must be replaced. Provision is also made for other work that is necessary on the collection of volumes held by the Australian War Memorial. Additional provision is made, to the extent of £2,500, for the provision of an up-to-date film on the Australian War Memorial itself. The film currently available is dated by the visit of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth and does not show the memorial as it is to-day.

talk.start.para: . - I refer to Division No. 251. An increase of about £500,000 is proposed in the appropriation for salaries and allowances, which suggests that there is a bigger work force. Item 05 in sub-division 2 shows a reduction of about £1,000 in provision for payments under the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Act. I should like to know why there is such a reduction if the work force is larger. I presume that there is a logical explanation. From the particulars on page 188 we note that the department employs, among its technical officers, a number of architects. However, item 15 of sub-division 2 relates to a proposed appropriation of £460,000 for fees of private architects and consultants. The expenditure on this item last year amounted to £257,573. This suggests that greater use will be made of private architects and consultants. I am curious to know the reason for engaging private architects and consultants instead of enlarging the department's own force of technical men.

speech.para: My main purpose in rising is to bring to the notice of the Minister some of the workings of the department in South Australia. The Department of Works is responsible for works performed on behalf of other departments. On the occasion of the erection of a post office at St. Mary's, in South Australia, a group of plasterers employed by sub-contractors was not paid. I rang the Department of Works, spoke to a clerk of works, and asked what the trouble was. He said, " Frankly, Mr. Cavanagh, the trouble with this department is that it pursues a policy of letting work to the lowest tenderer. As you know, in South Australia we have many mediocre or pseudo builders, who get contracts although they have not the capabilities to carry them out. As a result, the department suffers, there is greater cost because of additional supervision, work has to be re-done, and the structure is weakened by the breaking of the bond of brickwork ". That job was not up to specifications and had to be brought somewhere near that standard before the department could pay. Subsequently the officer told me that the chap had been back, and although it was not a first-class job it was the best that could be done by this individual, and the department was prepared to pay. The department was thus accepting secondgrade work because of its policy of letting to the lowest tenderer without inquiring into his bona fides.

There is a long list of such jobs in South Australia. The very important Curriestreet post office was finished some two years ago. The plasterers on that job have not yet been paid for their labour, which is all they have to sell to support their wives and families. This practice is wholesale in South Australia because of the Government's method of engaging contractors. It should eliminate this system. On the Currie-street job the sub-contract for plastering was given to a nineteenyearold New Australian who could not speak English. He had spent only six months with his brother, labouring for a plasterer, but he was given this contract. He engaged qualified plasterers for the purpose of getting the job done. He paid them for a time, then he drew some money and left the job. They were not paid for two weeks' work.

Plasterers and plasterers' labourers on the psychoanalysis block now nearing completion at the Repatriation Hospital at Dawes-road have not been paid. This sort of thing is happening on departmental construction jobs in South Australia, and it is causing much concern. We expect it from the State Government, with its deliberate policy of trying to attract industries to the State by making it a lowwage State. Arbitration award rates are far in excess of what the State is prepared to pay. The State Government has a system of letting out jobs on piece-work to mediocre tradesmen and men without business acumen, and it does not care if the workmen are not paid. The result of that system, as I outlined in my maiden speech, is that the rate of bankruptcies in South Australia is higher than that in any other State, in proportion to population. What is happening in Adelaide is causing much concern to the departmental officers. I ask the Minister whether he will make representations to the appropriate Minister to ensure that contracts for Government work carried out in South Australia are let only to competent and reputable contractors on the understanding that only day-labour employees will be engaged at award wages. I do not think that is too great a request to make in view of the illustrations that I have given.

I have given only some of the examples that have come to my notice. I daresay that there are many more. On numerous occasions in the past we have had to take action to obtain wages - many times without success - for work performed for the Department of Works on the Woomera Rocket Range. On the hospital job that was completed recently, when I left Adelaide the plasterers had not been paid the appropriate award wages. If the Government will assure us that this reasonable request will be acceded to in South Australia, many of the difficulties that we have faced in building construction in that State will be overcome and the department will be assured of getting a more competent job and a more tradesmanlike job, possibly at no extra cost when we consider the expense that is- incurred in the supervision of work done by incompetent employees.

talk.start.para: . - I refer to the appropriation for travelling and subsistence under Division No. 251. Last year, the appropriation was £270,400 and the expenditure was £274,884. This year, the appropriation is £320,000, or an increase of £46,000 over last year's expenditure. There must be some logical reason for the rather large increase. I hope the Minister will be able to give me some explanation of it. I also refer to item 10 in the same division - Motor vehicles - Maintenance and running expenses, including use of private vehicles for departmental purposes. The appropriation last year was £271,000 and the expenditure was £262,819. This year, the appropriation is £313,000, an increase of about £51,000 over the expenditure last year. Surely there is some explanation for that increase. I also want to know what is meant by the words, " use of private vehicles for departmental purposes ". If certain people connected with the Department of Works use their own vehicles and receive a mileage allowance for the use of them, I should like to know the rate of mileage allowance.

speech.para: I also wish to refer to the item mentioned by Senator Cavanagh - fees of private architects and consultants. The appropriation this year represents an increase of about £203,000 over the expenditure last year. The reason cannot be that there is a shortage of architects and consultants in Australia, because apparently the department is able to get private people to do this work. I wonder whether there is any substance in the suggestion that employees of the Commonwealth are not receiving a rate of pay commensurate with the rate they could receive outside the Public Service. Has that any relation to the need to spend £460,000 this year on fees to private architects and consultants?

The appropriation for repairs and maintenance for this department last year was £500,000 and the expenditure was £412,067. The appropriation this year is £400,000. About two years ago, the Western Australian federal members' rooms were moved out of the old Commonwealth Bank building into a floor of a new Commonwealth Bank building on the corner of William and Hay streets. The accommodation that is provided for federal members and senators in the new building is sub-standard. Although I have not been in many of the other federal members' rooms throughout Australia, those in which I have been - with the exception of the Melbourne rooms - are very much superior to those in Perth.

Although we have moved into the new building, so inferior are the rooms that, in order to get some privacy when speaking to a constituent who came in to see him, one member of the House of Representatives preferred to go down into the street and interview his constituent. The partition between my room and the next room is not sound-proof at all. In fact, you can see between the partition boards. Some time ago Mr. Beazley complained about the noise in his room and something was done about it. Up to date that is the only room that has been touched.

I have corresponded with the Department of the Interior in Western Australia on this matter for more than twelve months. The last information I had from the department was that the work would be carried out when funds became available. It expected that funds would become available about last March; but the funds are not yet available. However, I notice that on this occasion the relevant appropriation is being reduced. Does this appropriation include sufficient money to sound-proof the rooms in Perth so that members and senators will be able properly to interview people who come in to see them? We must remember that many people who come in to see members and senators regard the information that they want to give the member or senator as confidential. If they go into a room and they can hear voices from the room next door or they can hear some one talking on a telephone, they are not inclined to speak confidentially to the member or senator.

In my opinion, it is a disgrace for the Government to provide such offices. If the Government wanted us all to be in one community, why did it put in the partitions? Why did it not throw the floor open and let us sit down wherever we liked? It is absolutely ridiculous to put in partitions that are not sound-proof, and that you can see through.

talk.start.para: - Did you say that this was a new construction?
- Yes, these rooms have been constructed within the last two years.
- Then why are you agreeing to this appropriation of money?

- I understand that the position is that the Department of the Interior rents the whole floor. The partitions between the rooms do not belong to the Commonwealth Bank, but are the property of the department. The department took over the whole floor and then decided to divide it into offices. If and when the department moves out of this floor, it will take the partitions out because they do not belong to the bank. Even the Ministers who have suites of rooms in this building have complained - that is all of them with the exception of the Minister for the Interior, who is quite satisfied. I can assure the committee that there is no other honorable member or honorable senator satisfied with the accommodation that is provided.

speech.para: In addition, the lighting in the rooms is bad. In this modern building the rooms on the whole floor are artificially lit. Girls who work there complain about headaches and sore eyes because of the artificial lighting. It is bad architecturally to have so many rooms without natural light. I know that some honorable members and honorable senators have requested permission to use rooms in other buildings because they do not like the accommodation that is provided for them, but the Department of the Interior has refused their request, except in the case of the honorable member for

Swan (Mr. Cleaver). He is the only member who is allowed to have a room outside the Commonwealth Parliament Offices. Every other member from Western Australia has to occupy the offices, but he can remain outside. I should like the Minister to give me some explanation of this position; and perhaps he may be able also to give some assurance that the work required to be done on this building will be attended to.

talk.start.para: . - I should like to support the remarks made by Senator Cant. As a matter of fact I rose previously intending to initiate a debate on this particular subject. I too was wondering why this huge expenditure on fees for private architects and consultants is provided when a high standard of work can be performed by architects in the Department of Works. Last Saturday I had the privilege of witnessing the opening of the new airport terminal which was designed by architects of the Department of Works, and I am sure that it ranks among the best of its kind in the world. I have seen some overseas terminals and I have not seen anything better. My only criticism is that it does not contain a ladies' lounge, as I mentioned a little time ago. With that reservation, I am certain that this airport terminal ranks very high in comparison with similar buildings anywhere in the world.

speech.para: Whilst we have architects of such a high standard within the Department of Works I do not think it should be necessary to seek the services of architects outside the department. I do not know who is responsible for the architecture of the building in which federal members are inadequately housed in Perth. I understand it was not originally meant for federal members, but every other department refused to go into it and it was decided that as the federal members were in Canberra they should go into it and keep quiet about it. I raised this matter previously, as did Senator Robertson when she was a member of this chamber. Both of us complained about the artificial lighting and lack of ventilation. The building is air-conditioned - when the air-conditioning installation works. On some occasions the temperature is so high that it is a menace to health, particularly during the winter. The air conditioning is never regulated. I discussed this problem last Saturday with some architects of the Department of Works when we were at the opening of the airport. They said that the trouble was that the air-conditioning plant was put in piece-meal. Instead of having an air-conditioning plant put in at the commencement for the building as a whole, the air conditioning was installed on one floor at a time. If a complete air-conditioning unit had been put in as the Department of Works desired, the present difficulties would not have arisen.

I wish to stress particularly the inadequate lighting and the inadequacy of the rooms from the point of view of privacy. My room is in the middle of the building and is attached to three other offices. Every time I use the telephone the conversation can be heard in each of the three offices, no matter how I try to keep my voice down. It is not fair that that should be so, because as honorable senators know, people come to us with problems that they want to discuss in private. I have had difficulty also with eye strain. The Ministers' suites are the only rooms that have natural lighting. I do not begrudge that facility to them. I am glad that they have excellent suites because one of these days we will have them.

One office in the building was unoccupied for more than twelve months. It was the only office that had natural lighting. I applied to the department for permission to use it as it was being used only as a storeroom. I was told by the officer in charge of the Commonwealth Parliament Offices in Perth that I could not have this room because it was intended to furnish it at Ministerial level with wall-to-wall carpet. It has since been given, I understand, to the public relations officer for the Commonwealth Games.

talk.start.para: - It is being used by the News and Information Bureau.

- Senator Cant informs me that it is being used by the News and Information Bureau. It was too good a suite for an honorable senator of the Commonwealth Parliament with nearly twenty years service, but it could be given to an officer of the department.

speech.para: I have asked for new furniture from time to time. My room was furnished originally in 1943 with bits and pieces from everywhere, and none of it' matches. Everybody seemed to be getting new furniture but apparently mine was quite good enough. People coming to interview me have fallen on the old carpet because it does not fit the room at all. It has been moved from five different offices, and dropped on the road by carriers in the process of being moved from one place to another. Every time I try to get new furniture I am told that no money is available. I hope that the Government will see that sufficient money is made available under the estimates we are discussing to ensure that these rooms are adequately maintained and there is adequate provision made for those who are trying to carry out the job the people have elected them to the Senate to do. We do not want extravagance, but we want the minimum that is necessary to enable us to do a decent job.

- I will amend my statement and say that I will attend to the matter next week. Senator Cavanagh asked for information about Division No. 251 and the reason for the increase of £120,000. speech.para: The honorable senator sought information concerning compensation, and suggested that the reduced provision this year might indicate trends about which he was concerned. Payments under the act in respect of accidents to staff personnel are charged to this item as they arise. Therefore, only a nominal provision can be made. So far as the compensation rates are concerned, I think it is fair to say that the Government always honours its obligations.

The honorable senator asked about architects' fees. The increase amounts to £202,327. Provision is made under this item to meet the cost of private architects, engineers and quantity surveyors who are engaged to prepare plans and specifications for projects which cannot be undertaken within the department because of the shortage of professional staff. I think it is fair to say that any employment which will help the labour force and relieve unemployment is to be commended. This is a case in which the Government has departed from its usual policy in order to meet a situation. Current commissions include such items as extensions to the nurses' quarters at the Canberra Community Hospital, the Reserve Bank and projects in Papua and New Guinea. In addition to the planning of works which it is desired to start as soon as possible, it is important that we proceed with the design of works projects which can then be commenced at short notice in accordance with Government policy. The increase of £202,427 is also related to programmes under the administration of Papua and New Guinea.

The honorable senator also had a good deal to say about the acceptance of tenders, suggesting that the department always accepted the lowest tender and did not always get satisfaction. The policy of the department is to accept the lowest tender when the department is satisfied that the tenderer has the resources and is capable of carrying out the work. If investigations indicate that the lowest tenderer cannot satisfactorily fulfil the contract, the next lowest tender is considered. Ever since I have been a member of this chamber, this argument has arisen. There are two schools of thought. One is that the lowest tender should be accepted always. The other school argues, I think with more justification, that it is desirable to accept the lowest tender, but if the tenderer cannot give evidence of his ability and financial stability to perform the contract according to the requirements of the department, he should be passed over and the next tenderer given the contract. That is Government policy.

talk.start.para: asked for information concerning motor vehicles used for inspections. Senator Tangney, in her own inimitable way, gave a rather graphic description of the disabilities suffered by members of the Commonwealth Parliament in the federal members' rooms at Perth. I cannot give the honorable senator an undertaking that these disabilities will be remedied but I can assure her that I will refer these matters to the Minister for the Interior (Mr. Freeth).

.- I have listened fairly carefully to the Minister for Health, and have given as much understanding as I can to his explanations, but his references to two items leave me unsatisfied. I refer to two items which may be quite significant under Division No. 251. The first is the provision for travelling and subsistence. speech.para: I understand that prices are now stable. I want these items analysed, and I ask the Minister to tell me what are the factors within each of these items that warrant the increased expenditure. I should have thought that an item of this kind would be fairly consistent as to quantum year after year, and that there could be no justification for any significant increase in the unit cost price.

talk.start.para: . - I do not want to engage in polemics or political bigotry about the questions I raised to-night, but I think that some further protection should be given to the people for whom I made a claim. While I understand the matter of tenders, 1 emphasize that the unfortunate workers in South Australia are under a dictatorship and need special protection, even more than do workers in a State where they have the right to choose their own government. The system of employing labour in South Australia does not permit of the winning of award wages. Having regard to the peculiar circumstances in South Australia, I ask the Minister to consider the advisability of making it a condition of Commonwealth contracts that the workers shall be protected by ensuring that they receive the weekly award rate for the job they are doing. I also ask him to make it a condition of contracts that the contractor shall be willing to employ day labour on construction jobs.

speech.para: The statement that I made previously was not a false one. It was made as the result of a conversation I had with an officer of the department in Adelaide. Dissatisfaction had been expressed with the attitude of the department because contracts for the construction of buildings had been let to contractors although, on their past records, they had no hope of carrying out the contracts. The system in South Australia encourages the letting of contracts to sub-contractors with no business acumen or craft ability, .with the result that there is no possibility of the subcontracts being carried out. Those who suffer are the men who are employed.

This Government is supposed to believe in freedom and democracy. The workers of South Australia, who have no other form of redress because of the electoral system in that State, look to the Government to see to it that in the letting of Commonwealth Government contracts the workers are given the protection they so rightly deserve. I ask the Minister to take this action, not in a spirit of hostility but because of a desire to assist the day labour force, which is possibly the largest section of citizens in the community, to earn a living and to be paid the proper wage for its work.

This item provides for the fares of officers travelling on official business, together with travelling allowances while passing from their home station and settling-in allowances where applicable. The increase of £45,116 is made up as follows: - Recruitment of additional staff for Papua and New Guinea, £15,000; increased travel within Papua-New Guinea in relation to increased works programmes, £6,000; recruitment of professional officers overseas, £12,000. I am afraid I cannot add anything to this written explanation, because I have no first-hand knowledge of the undertakings to which the increases apply. On the surface of the explanation, however, it appears that there is a rapidly expanding programme in the Territories and that the Government has taken the action that it considers necessary.

speech.para: Senator Wrightalso asked, for further information concerning the increased appropriation under item 10, Motor vehicles - maintenance and running expenses. I previously informed him that the increase of ?50,181 over expenditure in 1961-62 is due largely to a change in costing procedure at the Weapons Research Establishment in South Australia. The explanatory note is, of course, a statement of fact, and I am sure the honorable senator does not expect me to elaborate on that written word. If he would like information concerning the details of the costing system that has been changed, I shall endeavour to get it for him.

Senator Cavanaghhas again emphasized what he describes as the plight of some of the workmen on government contracts who have not been able to draw their wages from the sub-contractors when they were due. I should like the honorable senator to know that the Government and honorable senators on this side of the chamber are just as jealous of the rights of the working people as are honorable senators opposite. That is a first charge on every job, and the Government has a policy which provides for that charge to be met. The department's contract provisions give some sub-contractors redress. The department may pay them direct by making deductions from progress payments due to the contractor. That is our general policy. I go further and say to Senator Cavanagh that I shall personally bring to the notice of my colleague, the Minister for the Interior, the points that he has raised. I assure him that the Minister will not be slothful in examining the complaints that the honorable senator has placed before the committee.

talk.start.para: . - When the Minister raises with his colleague the points concerning tenders that have been made by Senator Cavanagh, I wonder whether he would have a further look at the system of tendering. He may recall that I was interested in this matter a few months ago and that I referred to it on two occasions. It is interesting to me that Senator Cavanagh, who comes from South Australia, should be raising the matter from a South Australian point of view. I think that every honorable senator from time to time has brought before him disturbing facts concerning the letting of government contracts. Senator Wade said that it is not government policy to accept the lowest tender. I do not think anybody quarrels with that position as it applies to the letting of small tenders. In respect of contracts for which there is no special specification, such as the building of an aerodrome or some other government work - the Government is not bound to accept the lowest tender. It is possible that a tender will be submitted by a person who has no experience in that type of building construction, or indeed in any type of building construction at all. One of the great problems under our Commonwealth system is that the Department of Works takes over the construction of all building required by all departments. Honorable senators can appreciate how frustrating it must be to, say, the Postal Department or the Department of Civil Aviation to find that control over building .work required by it is exercised by the Department of Works. Probably the system is a good one over all, but it does give rise to certain problems when so many Commonwealth departments are involved.

speech.para: As the Minister will well know, there are many different types of contracts. With the open type of contract where nothing specific is set out, nobody would be so foolish as to bind himself to accept the lowest tender. The question about which I am concerned relates to problems arising out of special contracts. Matters relating to these contracts come across my desk every few months, and I have no doubt that other honorable senators have a similar experience. In cases where special types of contracts are to be let, the officers of the department call before them all those interested in tendering for the work. They then vet all the prospective tenderers. They question these men as to their bank balances, the type of work they have done, the amount of machinery they can put on to the proposed work-

talk.start.para: - But that is in their own interests.
- Let us have a look at this question.
- That saves them unnecessary expense in costing a job which they may not be adequately equipped to undertake.

- That is the very point on which I think the Minister has been misled by somebody. It is very good to bring these men in, not only for their own protection, but also for the protection of the Government. There is no argument about that. I suggest that instead of interjecting the Minister might let me make my speech. He can make his later. The matter to which I am referring comes across my desk frequently. The Minister is laughing at what I am saying. I hope he gets a good deal of fun out of it. But it is not funny to those people who, after being brought before the departmental officers to be examined as to their financial standing, their ability, and the amount of machinery, equipment and man-power they have available to do the work, are told that they may submit a tender but that the lowest tender will not necessarily be accepted. I know that it is difficult for the Government to pin itself down to anything definite, but I believe that if, after examining, say, twelve contractors, six are told that they are not suitably equipped to tender and six are told that their tenders will be considered, it is not right to say to the six who are given permission to tender that the lowest tender will not necessarily be accepted.

speech.para: As I said at the outset, I raise this matter only for the purpose of asking Senator Wade, when he is having his promised conversation with the Minister for the Interior (Mr. Freeth), to impress upon the Minister for the Interior that difficulties and distress can be caused in every State by this method of seeking tenders for certain types of contracts. Senator Wade interjected that these people were examined for their own protection. I am just wondering whether it is for their own protection if the Government will not bind itself down to accepting the lowest tender. Let me remind the Minister that it costs money to submit these tenders. I think that most of the big contractors allow from 2 per cent, to 3 per cent, for drawing up plans and submitting tenders when costing their jobs. Let me remind the Minister, too, that the amounts of tenders are no secret amongst the big contracting fraternity. With this system of not necessarily accepting the lowest tender A has no hesitation in telling B that his tender is £100,000, and B is equally unhesitant about telling A that the price he has submitted is £110,000. This is a very unsatisfactory state of affairs. I can understand the Government saying in certain instances that it will not necessarily accept the lowest tender, but I believe that at some point of time the Government will have to abide by the principle of accepting the lowest tender in those cases where it first vets prospective tenderers.

I know that we always receive a glib answer when we raise this matter, lt is not the first time that it has been mentioned here, as Senator Wade has stated, but I submit that the present system of calling for tenders does call for serious review. Believe me, when prospective tenderers are vetted by the officers of the department, they are examined very closely. They are questioned about their financial standing and their physical capacity to do the work and often a great deal of harm is done to them. In any case, in the final analysis, I do not think the Government is attaining the end at which it is aiming. In all fairness to these clients, these business associates of the Government, the Government should take the manly action of adopting a definite stand and abiding by it.

I come now to the question of payments under the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Act. The payment of compensation to Commonwealth employees was bitterly fought out first in the early 1920's and we have now reached the stage at which the Commonwealth has legislation governing the payment of compensation to its employees and the various States have legislation governing the payment of compensation to employees engaged under State awards. The result is that varying rates of compensation apply and this seems to me to be completely inequitable. It is completely wrong that when an employee of the Commonwealth is killed on his way to work his widow should be entitled to compensation while the widow of an employee of the Western Australian Government should receive no compensation for the death of her husband. That is a great weakness in our system. It is high time the Commonwealth set an example by reviewing the whole situation. It seems completely wrong that when, say, a lineman - and these men are accident-prone - with 20, 30 or 40 years service is killed the Government should magnanimously say to his widow, " Here is £3,000, we wash our hands completely of you, irrespective of whether you have one child or ten children, irrespective of whether you are in good health, irrespective of whether you are a widow of 50 or 60 years of age or whether you are a widow of 25 or 26 years of age". I think the Government is turning its back on its obligations towards its workers when it adopts that attitude.

Another matter which we fought vigorously on one occasion when the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Act was being amended related to the Commonwealth's right to move from place to place in order to evade that section of the act which provides for an appeal against the determination of departmental officers. When somebody is injured to-day and applies for compensation, the matter goes to one of those weird and wonderful officers in the Treasury Department and he makes a determination. That officer is not bound by precedent or anything else, and often this results in ridiculous situations. For instance, it does happen that where two accidents of the same type occur resulting in the same type of injury, different amounts of compensation are paid to the injured persons. The only redress the injured have is to appeal to the court. On more than one occasion, when an injured employee has initiated an appeal to the court against a determination of a Commonwealth officer, that officer makes a fresh determination on the eve of the hearing of the appeal. The result of this is that the injured employee is forced to withdraw his appeal and consider the second determination. If he is not satisfied with the new determination, he seeks to move the court of appeal again. By continuing to make fresh determinations on the eve of the hearing of appeals, the Commonwealth can prevent an injured employee from getting before the court. That was challenged in the High Court, which held that the Commonwealth was completely within its rights, according to the way the act was framed.

I feel confident that if the Minister consults expert opinion both inside the Cabinet and outside it, he will get a lot of advice completely negating this proposition. I think it is completely intolerable that while establishing a right of appeal under the Commonwealth Employees Compensation Act, the Commonwealth should reserve the right to move away from the properly constituted appeal body by making a fresh determination. One point about the law that worries us is that the Commonwealth has on its side the money, the time and the skilled advice, and that it will finally wear out the person who is not skilled in these matters and has not sufficient money to continue. When a person is injured and is dissatisfied with his compensation, he should have at least a limited right to recourse to the law without delay, but an unwritten law allows the Commonwealth to move away from this situation.

The position with regard to tenders is completely unsatisfactory. This is not a personal complaint on my part alone. Too many people are coming to too many of us in relation to this unsatisfactory system of tendering. It is not enough to be told that one has just missed being granted a contract. The Commonwealth is putting the old smear on a person who is thrown out after having been examined by the department and allowed to incur the expense of an application, the contract then not being awarded to the lowest tenderer. My second point is that, whilst the whole basis of Commonwealth employees' compensation should be examined, more specifically it is high time that the Government looked at the question of negating the appeal provision that is written into the act.

talk.start.para: .- Interesting as is Senator Willesee's reference to workers' compensation, it is quite obvious that it is relevant to the estimates for the Department of the Treasury, which administers the act, and falls off the loose peg on which Senator Willesee hung it, the compensation paid by the Department of Works. That is by the way. I rise only to show a pursuing interest in a matter I raised earlier, which the Minister has been fair enough to indicate he has not fully explained. In explanation of the increase of about £45,000 in travelling and subsistence expenses, one item read out to me related to recruitment of professional staff, I think overseas.
- That is so.

- That amounted to £12,000. This needs some explanation, does it not? We want to know, in this year of grace, with unemployment what it was in Australia, why the Department of Works is spending £12,000 on travelling and subsistence, in relation to overseas trips for the recruiting of professional assistance for this department.

speech.para: With regard to item 10, please do not ask us to accept such an explanation under such an elusive and confusing heading as " Motor vehicles - Maintenance and running expenses . . ." in a year in which there has been no increase in sales tax. Do not ask us simply to accept the suggestion that there has been an alteration in the method of costing, I think, at Woomera. Will the Minister, to avoid my tedious pressing of him in the committee stages, if.no one else is interested, be good enough to see that an officer, either personally or in writing, supplies me with details of these two items of expenditure before the middle of next week? I want them before the Estimates finally pass this chamber. I shall not say why.

I believe that the committee should be interested in whether or not unit costs in this department have increased, and if so by what percentage in the last year. I have picked two items which I thought were indicative, but the analysis that has been given from the ministerial table has not been useful in explaining them as an indications of unit costs. Item 11, maintenance of office machines, shows a proposed appropriation of £7,000. The expenditure last year was £5,704. What is the reason for this increase? What is the reason for any increase whatever in the cost from 1961 to 1962? If we go through the department, there should be at least twenty essential items upon which the department has unit costs as a basis for its checking of tenders. I want to know whether the department is proceeding upon the same unit costs this year as last year in, say, twenty items, in relation to its building construction. That will show whether we are still on the escalator, going up on the cost spiral, or whether we can rely upon having attained some reasonable stability.

talk.start.para: . - Senator Wright asked for an undertaking that he be supplied with certain information, in writing or personally, by next week. I shall be very happy to give him that assurance. From my discussions with officers of the department, I think that there is a very satisfactory explanation for the increases. I do not question for a moment Senator Wright's search for detail. That is the prerogative of every honorable senator.

speech.para: I would that I had time to join issue with Senator Willesee on the method of tendering. I was a member of the Public Accounts Committee when this matter was discussed at great length. Evidence was produced, witnesses were heard, and a great deal of research was done into this method of tendering. For my part, I am completely sold on the present system. I think it is in the best interests of every one concerned. It eliminates patronage, and it provides all the means of making government tendering the right of any interested person. I shall bring the honorable senator's submissions to my colleague, the Minister for the Interior (Mr. Freeth), who makes the decisions. I shall give one other undertaking. If the honorable senator can produce to the Minister specific cases of injustice to a prospective tenderer, the Minister for the Interior will examine them to see that there is no repetition of such injustice.
